content: The "Anna Westin Act of 2015" includes sections on short title, table of contents, findings, definitions, training and education, public service announcements, and more. The Congress finds that anorexia nervosa poses a high risk of death, with at least one person dying every 62 minutes from an eating disorder. Health consequences like osteoporosis and cardiac issues are significant burdens. Approximately 14.5 million people in the US suffer from eating disorders, with adolescents being particularly affected. Eating disorders are treatable biopsychosocial conditions. Eating disorders, including anorexia nervosa, are treatable biopsychosocial illnesses with high comorbidity rates. Anorexia nervosa is characterized by self-starvation, weight loss, and serious health consequences like heart failure and osteoporosis. Bulimia nervosa has a lifetime prevalence of 0.9-1.5% among women. Bulimia nervosa has a lifetime prevalence of 0.9-1.5% among women and 0.1-0.5% among men, with serious health consequences such as cardiac, gastrointestinal, and dental problems. Binge eating disorder, characterized by frequent episodes of uncontrolled overeating, affects 3.5% of women and 2.0% of men in the United States, often leading to obesity and other health issues. (10) Binge eating is linked to obesity, high blood pressure, elevated cholesterol and triglyceride levels, increased cancer and diabetes risk, and joint damage. Many exhibit symptoms of anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, or binge eating disorder. Eating disorders are more common in women but also occur in men. Rates of binge eating disorder are similar in both genders. Academic evidence supports these connections. Eating disorders affect individuals of all ages, races, and socioeconomic backgrounds in the US. They are associated with psychological issues like depression, substance abuse, and suicide. Hospitalizations for eating disorders in children under 12 increased by 119% between 1999 and 2006. Academic research shows a link between using very thin models in advertising and consumer behavior, including purchase intent and reliance on such advertising. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "eating disorder" to include various disorders like anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. SEC. 5. TRAINING AND EDUCATION. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will update and reinstate the BodyWise Handbook and related resources to include information on eating disorders for males and females. This information will be incorporated into the curriculum of the BodyWorks obesity prevention program. The BodyWise Handbook and related resources will be integrated into the BodyWorks obesity prevention program curriculum. The program will be updated and made publicly available for educating universities and nonprofit entities on eating disorders. SEC. 6. EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR HEALTH PROFESSIONALS. The Secretary will award grants to integrate training on eating disorders into existing curricula for healthcare professionals, including early intervention, treatment levels, referral procedures, prevention strategies, and treatment approaches. Eligible entities can apply for these grants. An entity seeking a grant must submit an application to the Secretary, including a plan for fund usage and training evaluation. The grant funds are to be used for developing a training program on eating disorders, including educational training, conferences, Internet-based courses, and teleconferences. The grant funds are used for educational training and conferences on preventing, identifying, and treating eating disorders. The program includes Internet-based courses and teleconferences to assess health risk factors and treatment plans. Evaluation and reporting to the Secretary are required. The grant funds are used for educational training and conferences on preventing, identifying, and treating eating disorders. The program includes Internet-based courses and teleconferences to assess health risk factors and treatment plans. Evaluation and reporting to the Secretary are required, including conducting a comprehensive assessment of a treatment plan and evaluating the effectiveness of the training provided in changing attitudes and behaviors of trainees. SEC. 7. EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR SCHOOL AND HIGHER EDUCATION PROFESSIONALS. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for educational seminars on early identification, intervention, and prevention of behaviors associated with eating disorders, as well as providing resources to affected individuals. Eligible entities must agree to conduct seminars considering materials from the BodyWise eating disorder initiative and relevant research. The Department of Health and Human Services offers educational materials through the BodyWise eating disorder initiative. An eligible entity includes states, territories, Indian tribes, and educational institutions. SEC. 8. PUBLIC SERVICE ANNOUNCEMENTS. The Director of the National Institute of Mental Health will conduct public service announcements to educate the public on eating disorders, including types, seriousness, identification, prevention, discrimination, media effects, and signs/symptoms. Collaboration with centers of excellence is required. The Director of the National Institute of Mental Health will collaborate with centers of excellence and community-based national nonprofit resources to address eating disorders and body image issues. SEC. 9. CLARIFYING APPLICATION OF EXISTING PARITY LAW. Section 2726 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to address the treatment of permanent exclusions under mental health and substance use disorder benefits in group health plans or health insurance coverage. Additionally, a new subsection is added regarding residential treatment. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new subsection on residential treatment for mental health and substance use disorder benefits. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act is also amended to address permanent exclusions under these benefits in group health plans or insurance coverage. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act is amended to address permanent exclusions under mental health and substance use disorder benefits in group health plans. This includes residential treatment as part of these benefits. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act is amended to address permanent exclusions under mental health and substance use disorder benefits in group health plans, including residential treatment. This does not expand the scope of mental health or addiction services under existing laws. No additional funds are authorized for this Act or its amendments; existing funds will be used instead.
